feed.title: NewsTracker: ukraine
feed.subtitle: This is a news tracking demo

entry.title: Ukraine PM says reforms continue despite 'lunatic' lawmakers
entry.summary:
He suggested he was optimistic the U.S. would also start sending weapons that Ukraine says it needs to defend itself against Russian aggression.

Yatsenyuk's U.S. visit came amid growing global concerns over proposed legislation in Ukraine's parliament that would water down economic reforms demanded by the international community.

A day earlier, the International Monetary Fund insisted that Ukraine must "stay the course," suggesting that rolling back the reforms could jeopardize the IMF's $40 billion support package for Ukraine.

At the White House, President Barack Obama echoed the need for Ukraine to stick with austerity measures during a meeting Monday with Yatsenyuk and Vice President Joe Biden.

The White House said Obama and Biden welcomed Ukraine's "strong stand against populist measures that could undermine Ukraine's financial stability."

"The fact of the matter is Ukraine is now under siege. Russia is building military outposts on Ukrainian soil," Biden told the U.S.-Ukraine business forum.

entry.title: European lawmakers condemn Russia's actions in Crimea, Ukraine
entry.summary:
Representing more than 50 countries, 96 lawmakers on Thursday condemned Russia's "unilateral and unjustified assault on Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity."

Russia was absent from 40th anniversary meeting in the Finnish capital as its delegates were denied visas in line with the European Union's travel bans for Russia's actions in the Ukraine crisis.

entry.title: Ukraine's ex-PM sets up 'Ukraine salvation committee'
entry.summary: MOSCOW (AP) " Ukraine's former prime minister, in exile in Moscow, has announced the creation of a 'Ukraine salvation committee' and pushed for early presidential and parliamentary elections.

entry.title: U.S. Imposes Further Russia And Ukraine-Related Sanctions
entry.summary: The United States has imposed further Russia and Ukraine-related sanctions, including on Crimean port operators, former Ukrainian officials, and a former Russian gas trader.

entry.title: Reports: Ukraine bans Depardieu for 5 years
entry.summary:
Local news reports say Ukraine has banned actor Gerard Depardieu from entering the country for five years.

The news website Apostrof on Tuesday published what it said was a letter from Ukraine's national security service, the SBU, saying Depardieu has been banned "in the interest of ensuring the security of our state."

entry.title: Ukraine says Russian officer detained when truckload of weapons intercepted
Ukraine claims Russian officer detained
entry.summary:
MOSCOW (AP) - Ukraine's border guards service says it has detained a Russian officer who was driving a truck packed with weapons including rocket-propelled grenades.

Ukraine and Western countries contend Russia is providing troops and weaponry to eastern Ukraine's rebels, who have been fighting Ukrainian forces since April 2014 in a war that has killed at least 6,400 people.

entry.title: U.S. To Start Training Ukrainian Army Troops This Fall
entry.summary: "This training is part of our long-running defense cooperation with Ukraine."

entry.title: U.S. To Train Ukraine Military Following Russian Agression
entry.summary: Toner said he had nothing to announce on any new weapons for Ukraine and that the focus was on providing non-lethal aid.

entry.title: US to expand Ukraine military training
entry.summary: The White House said Biden and Poroshenko also talked about Ukraine's efforts to combat corruption and the urgency of seeking justice in the crash of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH-17, which was shot down over Ukraine just over a year ago.

entry.title: US to expand Ukraine military training
entry.summary: Spokesman Mark Toner said the new program would increase to more than $244 million the amount of U.S. security assistance provided to Ukraine since last year when conflict between Kiev and Russian-backed separatists escalated in the east of the country.

entry.title: US to expand Ukraine military training
entry.summary: The State Department announced that the training would begin this fall in western Ukraine.

entry.title: Ukraine's new police on charm offensive in Kiev
entry.summary: In this photo taken, Wednesday, July 15, 2015, a couple takes a photograph with a Ukrainian police officer in downtown Kiev, Ukraine.

entry.title: Ukraine replaces entire police force to beat corruption
entry.summary: Just as in neighboring Russia, Ukraine's police corps was perceived as chronically extorting bribes and harassing citizens.

entry.title: Ukraine's new police on charm offensive in Kiev
entry.summary:
KIEV, Ukraine - Only a few months ago, Kiev residents would normally avoid the police if they could help it.

One of the pledges of the new Kiev government, which took over last year after pro-Russian President Viktor Yanukovych fled the country, was to combat rampant corruption in Ukraine's police.

entry.title: Cars of OSCE observers vandalized in eastern Ukraine
entry.summary: A demonstrator uses spray-paint to deface the windshield of a car of the OSCE and the International Committee of the Red Cross during a protest in Donetsk, eastern Ukraine, Thursday, July 23, 2015.

entry.title: Cars of OSCE observers vandalized in eastern Ukraine
Ukraine's justice ministry bars Communists from running in upcoming local elections
entry.summary:
KIEV, Ukraine - Ukraine's justice ministry has barred three Communist parties from running in the upcoming local elections, citing recent legislation.

The Communist party has been an important force in Ukraine, polling 13 percent in the 2012 parliamentary election, but its popularity plummeted over its support for ex-President Viktor Yunukovych.

In last year's parliamentary election the Communist Party of Ukraine garnered less than 4 percent of the vote.

Ukraine passed several laws in April banning the use of symbols from the Soviet years and denouncing Communist ideology.

entry.title: Volunteer named governor in eastern Ukraine
entry.summary: Since hostilities broke out in eastern Ukraine in April 2014, killing more than 6,400 people, the Ukrainian government has controlled only parts of the Donetsk and Luhansk regions.

entry.title: Ukraine rebels say their small weapons pullback is beginning
Ukrainian rebels claim to be pulling back smaller weapons from front line in eastern Ukraine
entry.summary:
MOSCOW - Ukraine's separatist rebels say they have begun pulling back military vehicles with small-caliber weapons from most of the front line in their war with Ukrainian forces.

The rebels said tanks and armored vehicles with weapons under 100mm would be pulled back three kilometers (two miles) from most of front line in eastern Ukraine.

entry.title: Shelling in East Ukraine Kills Four Civilians, Soldier
entry.summary: DONETSK, Ukraine - Ukraine and pro-Russian rebels accused each other on Saturday of shelling residential areas despite a ceasefire, reporting four civilians and one soldier killed following a week of the deadliest fighting in over a month.

entry.title: Ukraine's rebels say they're ready to pull back tanks, many smaller weapons in eastern Ukraine
entry.summary: MOSCOW - Ukraine's Russia-backed separatist rebels say they are ready to pull back smaller-caliber weapons from much of the front line in eastern Ukraine.

entry.title: Ukraine rebels: Ready to pull back tanks, smaller weapons
MH17 crash: Ukraine points finger at Russia as families mark anniversary
entry.summary:
Ukraine has consistently blamed Russia, but President Petro Poroshenko's comments were his most direct to date.

Russia denies responsibility and in turn has pointed the finger at Ukraine, whose forces are fighting pro-Russian separatist rebels in the region of eastern Ukraine where the plane crashed to earth.

In rebel-held eastern Ukraine, a church service was held and residents joined a procession to a gravestone near the charred area where twisted metal and body parts came crashing down on July 17 last year.

Britain and Ukraine marked the anniversary with new appeals for an international tribunal to prosecute suspects, an option also favoured by Malaysia, Australia, the Netherlands and Belgium.

entry.title: Ukraine's parliament calls local elections in October, but not in rebel-held east or Crimea
entry.summary:
KIEV, Ukraine - The Ukrainian parliament has voted to call a local election across the country in October, but not in the rebel-occupied east.

The Kiev government has had no control over parts of eastern Ukraine since separatist rebels began fighting government forces there in April 2014, a conflict that has since claimed more than 6,400 lives.

An armistice signed in February by Ukraine, Russia and the Russia-backed rebels called for local elections in eastern rebel-held areas as one of the steps to toward a comprehensive cease-fire, which has not been reached yet.

entry.title: Ukraine, Australia mark sombre anniversary of Malaysian jet's downing
entry.summary: In Canberra, Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott unveiled a plaque inscribed with the names of Australian victims, which is set in soil that a police officer brought back from Ukraine.

entry.title: Australia and Ukraine mark deadly MH17 anniversary
entry.summary: Australia, Belgium, Malaysia, the Netherlands and Ukraine have asked the United Nations Security Council to establish an international criminal tribunal to prosecute those responsible for shooting down the plane.

entry.title: Australia unveils memorial for victims of Malaysian plane shot down over Ukraine 1 year ago
entry.summary:
SYDNEY - Australia is holding a memorial service to mark the anniversary of the Malaysian jetliner that was shot down over eastern Ukraine.

The plane was heading from Amsterdam to Kuala Lumpur when it was shot down over war-ravaged eastern Ukraine.

entry.title: Little certainty 1 year after airliner shot down in Ukraine
entry.summary: A year since a Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777 was blown out of the sky over war-ravaged eastern Ukraine, killing 298 people, there has been little definitive progress in determining what brought down Flight MH17.

entry.title: Little certainty 1 year after airliner shot down in Ukraine
entry.summary:
A draft version of the final report was circulated this month to representatives of Malaysia, Ukraine, the U.S., Russia, Britain, Australia and the Netherlands for their comments and suggested revisions.

The probe is being led by The Netherlands because 196 of the victims were Dutch, and Ukraine agreed to give Holland formal responsibility for the investigation.

In any case, Russian President Vladimir Putin has said, Ukraine is morally responsible for the crash because it occurred in a war that Russia claims was launched by Ukraine.

entry.title: Little certainty 1 year after airliner shot down in Ukraine
entry.summary: This investigation includes authorities from Ukraine, Malaysia and other countries whose nationals were among the victims, but Russia is not a participant.

entry.title: Fighting surges in east Ukraine
entry.summary:
Kiev: Pro-Russian rebels have mounted one of the heaviest attacks on government troops since a February peace accord, Ukraine said, as the two sides blamed each other for a surge in fighting in the country's east.

Manouvering in the Donetsk region of Ukraine, where fighting has surged in recent days.

entry.title: A year later, MH17 relatives grieve, wait for answers
entry.summary:
For many families of the 298 people killed when Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 was brought down July 17 last year over eastern Ukraine, uncertainty and agonizing waiting is still woven into the fabric of life a year later.

Ukraine blames Russian-backed separatist rebels, Moscow blames Ukraine.

entry.title: Canada and Ukraine announce 'milestone' free trade agreement
entry.summary:
Canada will eliminate tariffs on 99% of imports from Ukraine and increase exports to Ukraine by C$41.2m.

Meanwhile, financially troubled Ukraine will reduce tariffs on 86% of Canadian imports and increase exports to Canada by C$23.7m, mainly in the textile and metalworking industries.

entry.title: Ukraine PM says reforms continue despite 'lunatic' lawmakers
entry.summary: Ukraine's prime minister pushed back Monday against a pair of forces threatening to undermine his fragile government, likening members of Ukraine's parliament to "lunatics" while defending a nationalist militia that is locked in a standoff with police.

entry.title: Ukraine PM says reforms continue despite 'lunatic' lawmakers
entry.summary: Although the group has little formal involvement in Ukrainian politics, Russia has accused Ukraine's government of going too soft on the Right Sector, calling it evidence of Kiev's fascist leanings.

entry.title: AP Interview: Ukraine leader says economic reforms to continue despite 'lunatic' lawmakers
entry.summary: Obama has repeatedly conceded that tough economic sanctions imposed by the West have done little to change Russian President Vladimir Putin's decisions about Ukraine.

entry.title: General: US considers expanding Ukraine training to army
entry.summary: Sen. John McCain has been a vocal critic of the administration's approach, calling it timid and insufficiently supportive of the Ukraine government.

entry.title: General: US considers expanding Ukraine training to army
General: US considers expanding Ukraine training to army
entry.summary:
The United States rejects the claim and says Russian troops are backing separatist fighters in eastern Ukraine, violating that country's sovereignty.

"It's got to be something that Ukraine and the U.S. and other participating nations would all agree on," Hodges said, adding that it would be similar to the kinds of training now provided to national guardsmen near Lviv, close to the Polish border.

Ukraine has battled Russian-backed separatists in its eastern region since April 2014.

entry.title: Canadaâ€™s embassy used as haven for protesters during Ukraine uprising
Investigation uncovers Canadian embassy in Ukraine used as a haven in 2014 by anti-government protesters
entry.summary:
"Generally speaking in Ukrainian public opinion, as well in the Ukraine government of that time, there was a common understanding that Canadian sympathies are on the side of the protesters, pro-European, pro-democratic."

Dominque Arel, a noted expert on Ukraine at the University of Ottawa, agreed and said the perception that Canada was more than a disinterested bystander was formed long before the Maidan protests, which erupted in the fall of 2013, turned violent.

Waschek says the safety and security for diplomats is a paramount concern, and Canada's backing of democracy in Ukraine should surprise no one.

"You could say events are still raw because Crimea was annexed and eastern Ukraine was invaded," Suprun said.

"And as far as I can tell, the only country that has stood side by side with Ukraine has been Canada, even during the Maidan by closing the embassy in Moscow. These are the right things to do. In finding that friendship, you keep finding the strength to move forward."

entry.title: At least 2 killed in attack at Ukraine sports club
entry.summary: Mukachevo is in far western Ukraine, near the borders of Poland, Hungary and Slovakia.

entry.title: At least 2 dead in in Ukraine sports club attack
entry.summary: Armed activists of the nationalist militia Right Sector take position in the site of unrest in Mukhachevo, Western Ukraine, Saturday, July 11, 2015.

entry.title: At least 2 dead in in Ukraine sports club attack
entry.summary:
At least two people were killed Saturday in a gun and grenade attack in a western Ukraine city involving the country's notorious nationalist militia Right Sector.

Right Sector was one of the most militant factions in the massive protests in Ukraine's capital that led to pro-Russia President Viktor Yanukovych fleeing the country in February 2014.

entry.title: At least two dead in Ukraine sports centre attack
entry.summary: After war broke out in eastern Ukraine between government forces and pro-Russia separatists several months later, Right Sector has fought on the government side and Amnesty International has accused the group of holding civilians as prisoners and torturing them.

entry.title: Ukraine says 7 injured during armed attack in western city
entry.summary: Mukhachevo is in far western Ukraine, near the border with Poland and Slovakia.

entry.title: Ukraine says 7 wounded in armed gang attack in western city
entry.summary: MOSCOW (AP) " Ukraine's Interior Minister says four civilians and three police officers have been wounded in an attack by armed men whose weapons include grenades in a western city.

entry.title: Ukraine's self-defense units look for the enemy within
entry.summary:
Odessa lies more than 500 kilometers (300 miles) west of the front line in east Ukraine, where government troops are mired in a war of attrition against Russian-backed separatists.

Ibrahim's background is a vivid illustration of the eclectic mix of interests encompassed by the movement that militates for Ukraine to develop closer ties with Russia instead of the West.

Moscow's hand is seen behind much of the violent trouble that has hit Ukraine over the past year, including in Odessa.

entry.title: Ukraine's self-defense units look for the enemy within
entry.summary: In this photo taken on Thursday, June 25, 2015, members of a self-defense unit carry out exercise drills in a location outside Odessa, Ukraine.

entry.title: Gunman kills 3 postal workers in Ukraine, steals $115,000
entry.summary:
An unidentified gunman shot and killed three postal workers Friday as they were transporting money in eastern Ukraine, escaping with the equivalent of $115,000, police said.

Both the government of Ukraine and its people have been under severe economic stress recently.

Ukraine's economy is shrinking, with the IMF projecting a 9 percent contraction this year, and inflation topping 46 percent.
